awd_titl_txt: PFI-RP: Fostering Agricultural ReMote Sensing (FARMS) - use of unmanned aerial systems to enable precision agriculture.
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this PFI project, called the Fostering Agricultural ReMote Sensing Alliance, or FARMS Alliance, centers around the technology and data analytics of remote sensing from unmanned aircraft systems (UAS), with precision agriculture as the targeted application area. The efforts targets a proxy crop, snap bean, and three proxy applications prioritized by our industry partners as key to their commercial efforts, namely disease risk modeling, harvest timing/scheduling, and yield prediction to propel FARMS into a sustainable innovation ecosystem. This is essential, since although the UAS agricultural market is pegged at US$34.2B globally, the USA is lagging due to past restrictions on commercial UAS flights. The FARMS Alliance will find fertile ground for growth in Upstate NY, where the Finger Lakes Regional Economic Development Council has identified agriculture as a strategic growth area. This effort will afford the Finger Lakes region an opportunity to be a hub in the Eastern USA for agriculture and food production and with coordination, will lead to leadership and growth in the industry. Finally, at least four imaging science and six business graduate students will be trained at the nexus of imaging-precision-agriculture-business, equipped as truly trans-disciplinary scientists and managers.

The proposed project will contribute significantly to the identification of both spectral (color) and structural (3D) signatures from UAs platforms that are coupled to specific precision agriculture applications. We will improve on the relatively simple and generic current approaches, and develop new methods to distill oversampled UAS remote sensing data to the essence of metrics required for each application. This close collaboration between imaging scientists and plant physiologists will lead to turn-key, specific (optimized) solutions for our industry partners, to then market to the burgeoning precision agriculture economy. In short, expensive UAS systems will be used to derive commercial, affordable, and practical UAS solutions that can transition to the precision agriculture sector.  Finally, this approach will hedge consistent, reliable image processing via proper spectral calibration of the target scene and the instruments themselves - this sets the FARMS Alliance apart from similar, simple spectral metric solutions that currently are being offered by precision agriculture service providers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT) and Cornell University established a National science Foundation (NSF) Partnerships for Innovation (PFI) multidisciplinary academic/industrial innovation ecosystem, called the Fostering Agricultural ReMote Sensing Alliance, or FARMS Alliance, around the technology and data analytics of remote sensing from unmanned aircraft systems (UAS), with precision agriculture (PA) as the targeted application area. We focused on a proxy crop, snap bean, and three proxy applications prioritized by our industry partners as key to their commercial efforts, namely disease risk modeling, harvest timing/scheduling, and yield prediction to propel FARMS into a sustainable innovation ecosystem. We developed commercialize-ready UAS products based on the research. This was achieved with the help of imaging scientists, plant pathologists/physiologists, and business experts, where we trained imaging science PhD students and business MS students as cohorts, to explore market readiness.

Specifically, the NSF PFI FARMS Alliance Innovation Ecosystem was developed to

  1. deliver practical, integrated unmanned aerial systems (UAS)-based management strategies for a proxy crop (snap bean), with three precision agriculture “applications”: disease risk modeling, harvest scheduling, and yield modeling, all at the field and sub-field levels; for
  2. applications which were highlighted by an industry farming sector collaborator, with UAS workflows (algorithms) embedded in industry collaborators that focus on UAS, airborne, and spaceborne imaging platforms, and finally, service providers that can deliver crop grower products to market, all of which
  3. establishes a sustainable innovation ecosystem – an operational innovation-to-market recipe – to boost local, regional, state, and even national economies in terms of improved crop yields via innovative UAS technological solutions.

The project was successful in its broader impact goals by adding three additional industry partners, collecting UAS imagery for bean and beet crops, and delivering algorithms for assessing crop yield, harvest readiness, and disease risk. The project's intellectual merits revolve around the crop management algorithms, underpinned by robust image collection, processing, and analysis approaches. We have shown that we can accurately predict crop yield for managers to optimize harvest logistics, detect when to harvest (snap bean), thereby optimizing yield and product quality, and critically, we can detect disease, so growers can act to protect crops only when and where needed. This latter approach has obvious implications not only in terms of cost savings, but also in reducing environmental impacts of chemicals. These methods have been published and shared; in some instances these can now be adopted by industry service providers to embed in their UAS workflows to develop agricultural products to farmers.

We were successful in knowledge dissemination, as evidenced by six journal papers, as many as 14 conference proceedings presentations, and numerous outreach activities, also with our university collaborator, Cornell University. Finally, the project has led to training of our future workforce by graduating (or in the process of graduating) three imaging science PhD students, one imaging science MS student, and several business students.

In summary: The NSF-funded FARMS Alliance has led to the development of agricultural solutions for UAS (drones), to assess crop yield, harvest readiness, and detect disease in especially snap bean as a proxy crop, but also beets. These solutions can now be adopted by industry as service products, using readily-accessible UAS platforms. We have trained numerous students to enter and contribute to the agricultural and remote sensing workforce, while disseminating our outcomes to both technology adopters and the broader scientific community.


Last Modified: 10/09/2024
Modified by: Jan A Van Aardt
